title: AI Image Feedback Loop
content:
Data artist Robert Hodgin recently created a feedback loop between Midjourney and ChatGPT-4 â€” he prompted MJ to create an image of an old man in a messy room wearing a VR headset, asked ChatGPT to describe the image, then fed that description back into MJ to generate another image, and did that 10 times. Here was the first image:

And hereâ€™s one of the last images:

Recursive art like this has a long history â€” see Alvin Lucierâ€™s I Am Sitting in a Room from 1969 â€” but Hodginâ€™s project also hints at the challenges facing AI companies seeking to keep their training data free of material created by AI. Ted Chiang has encouraged us to â€œthink of ChatGPT as a blurry jpeg of all the text on the Webâ€:

It retains much of the information on the Web, in the same way that a jpeg retains much of the information of a higher-resolution image, but, if youâ€™re looking for an exact sequence of bits, you wonâ€™t find it; all you will ever get is an approximation. But, because the approximation is presented in the form of grammatical text, which ChatGPT excels at creating, itâ€™s usually acceptable. Youâ€™re still looking at a blurry jpeg, but the blurriness occurs in a way that doesnâ€™t make the picture as a whole look less sharp.

And we already know what you get if you recursively save JPEGsâ€¦

See also La Demoiselle dâ€™Instagram, I Am Sitting in a Room (with a video camera), Google Image Search Recursion, and Dueling Carls.
